questions.q: Let P(x,y) be the propositional function "x borrowed y's textbook", and let M(x) be the propositional function "x is enrolled in a calculus class". Let S be the set of students and L denote the set of library booksâ€”all at Riverside College. The domain of discourse of P is S x L, and the domain ofdiscourse of M is S. Write this proposition symbolically: Sarah borrowed someone's book from the library.
questions.explanation: Sarah is a specific student in the set S. y represents an element in the set L (library books) [Prompt]. P(Sarah,y) represents the propositional function "Sarah borrowed book y" [Prompt].

questions.q: Let P(x,y) be the propositional function "x borrowed y's textbook", and let M(x) be the propositional function "x is enrolled in a calculus class". Let S be the set of students and L denote the set of library booksâ€”all at Riverside College. The domain of discourse of P is S x L, and the domain ofdiscourse of M is S. Write this proposition symbolically: No one borrowed the Advanced Algebra textbook.
questions.explanation: No one: This indicates a negation of the existential quantifier or a universal quantification of a negation. The domain for "no one" (students) is the set S [Prompt]. The Advanced Algebra textbook: This refers to a specific element within the set of library books L [Prompt].
questions.answer: âˆ€xÂ¬P(x,Advanced Algebra textbook) or Â¬âˆƒxP(x,Advanced Algebra textbook)

questions.q: Let P(x,y) be the propositional function "x borrowed y's textbook", and let M(x) be the propositional function "x is enrolled in a calculus class". Let S be the set of students and L denote the set of library booksâ€”all at Riverside College. The domain of discourse of P is S x L, and the domain ofdiscourse of M is S. Write this proposition symbolically: Every calculus student borrowed someone's book from the library.
questions.explanation: âˆ€x: Denotes "Every student" within the domain S [Prompt, 13]. M(x)â†’: Restricts the statement to those enrolled in calculus. âˆƒyP(x,y): Expresses that there exists at least one book y in the library set L that the student borrowed [Prompt, 13, 134].

questions.q: Let P(x,y) be the propositional function "x borrowed y's textbook", and let M(x) be the propositional function "x is enrolled in a calculus class". Let S be the set of students and L denote the set of library booksâ€”all at Riverside College. The domain of discourse of P is S x L, and the domain ofdiscourse of M is S. Write this proposition symbolically: Every library book was borrowed by at least one student.
questions.explanation: âˆ€y: Represents "Every library book" within the domain L. âˆƒx: Represents "at least one student" within the domain S. P(x,y): The propositional function indicating that student x borrowed book y. Structure: This nested quantification expresses that for every book in the library, there is at least one student who borrowed it

questions.q: Prove by Contraposition that if n is an integer and nÂ³ + 5 is odd, then n is even.
questions.explanation: The contrapositive of 'if P then Q' is 'if not Q then not P'. Here P: nÂ³ + 5 odd, Q: n even. Contrapositive: if n odd, then nÂ³ + 5 even. Shown by direct proof.
questions.answer: Assume n is odd (not even). Then n = 2k + 1 for some integer k. nÂ³ = (2k + 1)Â³ = 8kÂ³ + 12kÂ² + 6k + 1 = even + 1 = odd. Then nÂ³ + 5 = odd + odd = even. Thus, if n is odd, nÂ³ + 5 is even (not odd). This is the contrapositive.

questions.q: Show that the following compound propositions are logically equivalent using the Rules: ((p âˆ¨ q) â†’ Â¬a) â‰¡ (a â†’ (Â¬q âˆ§ Â¬p))
questions.explanation: Using logical equivalences like implication law and De Morgan's laws.
questions.answer: Left side: (p âˆ¨ q) â†’ Â¬a = Â¬(p âˆ¨ q) âˆ¨ Â¬a (implication equivalence) = (Â¬p âˆ§ Â¬q) âˆ¨ Â¬a (De Morgan). Right side: a â†’ (Â¬q âˆ§ Â¬p) = Â¬a âˆ¨ (Â¬q âˆ§ Â¬p) (implication) = Â¬a âˆ¨ (Â¬p âˆ§ Â¬q) (commutative). Both sides equal.

questions.q: Show that the premises: i. "If Jo has a bacterial infection, she will take antibiotics." ii. "Jo gets a stomach ache when and only when she takes antibiotics and doesn't eat yogurt." iii. "Jo has a bacterial infection." iv. "Jo doesn't eat yogurt." Using rules of inference and logical equivalence to conclude "Jo gets a stomach ache.".
questions.explanation: Step-by-step application of rules of inference.
questions.answer: Let B: Jo has bacterial infection, A: takes antibiotics, S: gets stomach ache, Y: eats yogurt. Premises: B â†’ A, S â†” (A âˆ§ Â¬Y), B, Â¬Y. From B and B â†’ A: A (modus ponens). From A and Â¬Y: A âˆ§ Â¬Y (conjunction). From A âˆ§ Â¬Y and S â†” (A âˆ§ Â¬Y): S (biconditional elimination).

questions.explanation: The set {âˆ…} contains the empty set as its only element.
The empty set has no elements, so {âˆ…} (which has one element) is not a subset.
Same as statement 1; the empty set is an element of {âˆ…}.
Every element of {âˆ…} (which is âˆ…) is in {âˆ…, {âˆ…}}.
Every set is a subset of itself.

questions.q: Determine whether the following function is a bijection from â„ to â„: f(x) = (xÂ² + 1)/(xÂ² + 2)
questions.explanation: Not injective: f(x) = f(-x) for all x, but x â‰  -x for x â‰  0. Not surjective: range is [1/2, 1), not all â„.

questions.explanation: The power set has subsets âˆ…, {âˆ…}, {{âˆ…}}, {âˆ…, {âˆ…}}, where {{âˆ…}} is the same as {âˆ…, {âˆ…}} in notation consistency.
